vector2d

Class Vector2D

  • java.lang.Object
    • vector2d.Vector2D

  • public class Vector2D
extends java.lang.Object
    This class models a vector in two dimensions.

    Like a length (feet and inches), weight (pounds and ounces), time (hours and minutes), fraction (numerator and denominator), a complex number (real and imaginary parts), a 2D vector is a thing with two parts that can be added.

    Version:
    6 March 2013
    Author:
    CSC140 Foundations of Computer Science

      • Vector2D

        public Vector2D(double x,
                double y)
        A vector can represent a point.
        Parameters:
        x - is the x coordinate of the point.
        y - is the y coordinate of the point.

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public Vector2D add(Vector2D v)
        The addition of one vector to another produces a third vector.

        The components of the sum are the sums of the corresponding components of the vectors we add.

        $$ \begin{align*} \vec{u} & = (u_x, u_y ) \\ \vec{v} & = (v_x, v_y ) \\ \vec{u} + \vec{v} & = (u_x + v_x, u_y + v_y) \end{align*} $$
        Parameters:
        v - is the vector to be added to this one.
        Returns:
        the sum of this vector and the other vector.

      • scale

        public Vector2D scale(double xFactor,
                      double yFactor)
        Multiplication of the components of a vector stretches the vector. Scaling \(\vec{u} = (u_x, u_y)\) by \( (xFactor, yFactor) \) produces a new vector: \( (xFactor \cdot u_x, yFactor \cdot u_y) \).
        Parameters:
        xFactor - is the amount of horizontal stretching.
        yFactor - is the amount of vertical stretching.
        Returns:

      • scale

        public Vector2D scale(double factor)
        We will often want to stretch a vector the same amount in the horizontal and vertical directions. Scaling \(\vec{u} = (u_x, u_y)\) by \( factor \) produces a new vector: \( (factor \cdot u_x, factor \cdot u_y) \).

        If we think of a vector as an arrow, this operation produces a new vector that has the same (or opposite when the scale factor is negative) direction as the original but a different length.

        Parameters:
        factor - is the amount of stretching.
        Returns:
        a stretched (or contracted) vector.

      • rotate

        public Vector2D rotate(double angle)
        If we think of a vector as an arrow rooted at the origin, then we can imagine rotating it like the hand on a clock. Rotating a vector whose components are \( (u_x, u_y) \) by \( \psi \) radians produces a new vector whose components \( (x, y) \) are as follows: $$ \begin{align*} x & = u_x \cdot \cos \psi - u_y \cdot \sin \psi \\ y & = u_x \cdot \sin \psi + u_y \cdot \cos \psi \end{align*} $$
        Parameters:
        angle - is the amount of rotation.
        Returns:
        is a rotated version of this vector.

      • rotateScaleTranslate

        public Vector2D rotateScaleTranslate(double angle,
                                     double scaleX,
                                     double scaleY,
                                     double deltaX,
                                     double deltaY)
        We will often want to rotate, scale, and translate (move) a vector in that order.
        Parameters:
        angle - is the amount of rotation.
        scaleX - is the amount of horizontal stretching.
        scaleY - is the amount of vertical stretching.
        deltaX - is the distance moved in the horizontal direction.
        deltaY - is the distance moved in the vertical direction.
        Returns:
        is a rotated, scaled, and translated version of this vector.

      • dot

        public double dot(Vector2D v)
        The dot product of this vector with another vector gives us a number. $$ \begin{align*} \vec{u} & = (u_x, u_y) \\ \vec{v} & = (v_x, v_y) \\ \vec{u} \cdot \vec{v} & = u_x v_x + u_y v_y \end{align*} $$

        This number is the length of the one vector's projection on the other (the length of its shadow).

        Parameters:
        v - is the other vector in the dot product with this vector.
        Returns:
        is the sum of the products of the vector's corresponding components.

      • magnitude

        public double magnitude()
        The magnitude of a vector is its length. $$ \begin{align*} \vec{u} & = (u_x, u_y) \\ |\vec{u}| & = \sqrt{ u_x^2 + u_y^2 ) } \\ & = \sqrt{ \vec{u} \cdot \vec{u} } \end{align*} $$

        The magnitude is also the square root of the dot product of the vector with itself. This is just the same rule we use to find the length of the hypotenuse of a triangle.

        Returns:
        the length of the vector.

      • getX

        public double getX()
        Here's an accessor method to allow a read-only view of the vector's x component from methods in other classes.
        Returns:
        the value of the vector's x component.

      • getY

        public double getY()
        Here's an accessor method to allow a read-only view of the vector's y component from methods in other classes.
        Returns:
        the value of the vector's y component.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Here's a way to produce a printable representation of the vector.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        the components of the vector in parentheses and separated by a comma.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        More than one class in a program can have a main() method.

        main() methods are a convenient place to put code that tests the constructors and methods of a class.

        Parameters:
        args - is an array that we do not use but must include in every main() method.
